title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: Instrumental variable (IV) methods widely used economics, epidemiology, social sciences estimate causal effects treatment assignment confounded. valid IV approach requires, conditionally certain observed covariates, instrument confounded outcome, influences outcome affecting uptake treatment. recent literature, first assumption usually called exogeneity, ignorability, unconfoundedness instrument, whereas second assumption called exclusion restriction. assumptions can violated omitted confounders instrument-outcome association, omitted side-effects instrument influence outcome via paths treatment. assumptions may sometimes entail testable implications, often unverifiable must defended appealing domain knowledge. Whether given IV study identifies causal effect interest, , turns debates whether assumptions hold. worryingly, assumptions fail, bias IV estimate may worse original confounding bias naive regression estimate. Therefore, researchers advised perform sensitivity analyses assess degree violation required alter conclusions study. package iv.sensemakr implements sensitivity analysis framework IV estimates developed Cinelli Hazlett (2025), building omitted variable bias (OVB) tools Cinelli Hazlett (2020). provides tools : Quantify strong violations need – form side-effects (exclusion restriction violations) confounders (ignorability violations) – invalidate IV findings. Use observed covariates benchmarks calibrating plausible strength violations. Produce contour plots visualize IV confidence interval changes different assumptions strength omitted variables. Rather asking “IV assumptions violated?” (generally untestable), framework asks: “severely need violated change research conclusions?” answer given terms interpretable partial R2R^2 parameters, making easy researchers reviewers assess whether magnitude violation required plausible. main functions package : iv_fit() – fits IV model using Anderson-Rubin (AR) approach; sensemakr() – runs sensitivity analysis iv_fit object; plot() / ovb_contour_plot() – produces sensitivity contour plots; rv() / xrv() – computes robustness values; sensitivity_stats() – computes key sensitivity statistics.

what: OLS and the omitted variable bias problem
title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: Many observational studies established positive association educational achievement earnings using regression analysis. consider work Card (1995), employed sample n=3,010n = 3{,}010 individuals National Longitudinal Survey Young Men. regression log wages (YY) years education (DD), adjusting race, experience, regional factors (XX), Card found additional year schooling associated approximately 7.5% higher wages. However, educational achievement randomly assigned: individuals obtain education may higher wages reasons, family background, higher levels unobserved characteristic Ability Motivation. Regression estimates adjust partial list characteristics may thus suffer omitted variable bias, likely overestimating true returns schooling.

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: IV methods offer alternative route estimate causal effect schooling earnings without data unobserved variables. key find new variable (instrument) changes incentives educational achievement, associated earnings effect education. Card proposed exploiting role geographic differences college accessibility: variable Proximity encodes whether individual grew near four-year college (ZZ). Students grow far nearest college may face higher educational costs, discouraging pursuing higher level studies. IV estimate given ratio two OLS coefficients – one measuring effect Proximity Earnings (reduced form), another measuring effect Proximity Education (first stage): τ̂IV=λ̂RFθ̂FS\hat{\tau}_{IV} = \frac{\hat{\lambda}_{RF}}{\hat{\theta}_{FS}}

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: card dataset, included package, contains data NLSYM 3,010 observations. key variables : lwage: log hourly wage 1976 (outcome). educ: years completed education (treatment). nearc4: indicator proximity four-year college (instrument). Various covariates: exper, expersq, black, south, smsa, regional dummies, smsa66. function iv_fit() takes vectors outcome y, treatment d, instrument z, optional covariate matrix x. computes IV estimates using Anderson-Rubin (AR) approach, numerically equivalent Two-Stage Least Squares (2SLS) point estimation, constructs confidence intervals via test inversion – procedure correct coverage regardless instrument strength. first-stage coefficient reveals grew near college completed additional 0.32 years education, average. reduced-form shows proximity associated 4.2% higher earnings. IV estimate τ̂≈0.042/0.319≈0.132\hat\tau \approx 0.042/0.319 \approx 0.132, suggesting additional year schooling raises wages 13.2%. summary() method displays three underlying regressions (IV, first stage, reduced form): can use coef() confint() extract individual components:
code: # load the package library(iv.sensemakr)  # load the dataset data("card") # prepare data y <- card$lwage  # outcome: log wage d <- card$educ   # treatment: years of education z <- card$nearc4 # instrument: proximity to college x <- model.matrix(~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 +                      reg662 + reg663 + reg664 + reg665 + reg666 +                      reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card)  # fit the IV model card.fit <- iv_fit(y, d, z, x) card.fit #>  #> Instrumental Variable Estimation #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Moreover, presence college nearby may associated high school quality, turn also affects earnings. Finally, geographic factors can make localities likely colleges nearby lead higher earnings – coarsely conditioned observed regional indicators, residual biases may remain. Therefore, instead adjusting XX , adjusted observed covariates XXand unobserved covariates WW, WW stands unobserved factors necessary make Proximity valid instrument effect Education Earnings. question becomes: IV estimates model without WW compare estimates model WW?

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: iv.sensemakr framework parametrizes strength potential side-effects confounders using two partial R2R^2 measures: RZ∼W|X2R^2_{Z \sim W | X}: partial R2R^2 omitted variable(s) WW instrument ZZ, given observed covariates XX. measures much residual variation instrument “explained” WW. RY0∼W|Z,X2R^2_{Y_0 \sim W | Z, X}: partial R2R^2 WW potential outcome Y(0)Y(0), given ZZ XX. constant treatment effects model, simple interpretation – stands much residual variation confounders side-effects explain untreated potential outcome. partial R2R^2 values zero, IV assumptions hold estimate valid. values increase, bias grows. sensitivity analysis asks: combinations two parameters IV results change enough overturn research conclusions?

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: sensemakr() function takes iv_fit object computes sensitivity statistics. show call parameters made explicit, simplified version using defaults: cases, defaults appropriate: parameters control: benchmark_covariates: observed covariates used bound plausible strength omitted variables. use "black" "smsa" (metropolitan area indicator) reference points. kz, ky, kd: multipliers scale benchmark bounds. instance, kz = 2 asks “omitted variable twice strongly related instrument benchmark covariate?” q: fraction effect explained away. Default 1 (bring estimate zero). alpha: significance level hypothesis tests confidence intervals. min: TRUE (default), robustness value accounts biases large larger needed, yielding RV=min⁡(RVϕ,RVFS)RV = \min(RV_\phi, RV_{FS}).

IV robustness value minimum two. first stage strong (RVFSRV_{FS} large), robustness driven RVϕRV_\phi. case running example, binding constraint comes reduced form, first-stage strength. can access components directly: sensitivity_stats() function provides summary table including RV XRV alongside estimates confidence intervals: Note (extreme) robustness value IV estimate required bring lower limit confidence interval zero minimum (extreme) robustness value reduced form (extreme) robustness value first stage evaluated zero null. running example, reduced form fragile, thus sensitivity IV hinges critically sensitivity reduced form.

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: sensitivity analysis tools iv.sensemakr provide logical deductions aimed : () revealing consequences varying degrees violation IV assumptions (e.g., via bias-adjusted critical values), (ii) determining minimal degree violation necessary overturn certain conclusions (e.g., via robustness values). shifts scientific debate arguing whether latent confounders side-effects instrument exactly zero strength – indefensible claim settings – realistic discussion whether can confidently rule strengths shown problematic. results sensitivity analyses always self-evident can often surprising. may reveal certain studies highly sensitive plausible perturbations IV assumptions, others remain robust despite perturbations. running example, sensitivity analysis reveals returns--schooling IV estimate, statistically significant, can overturned confounders strong covariates already observed data (metropolitan area status race). calls careful discussion whether residual confounding plausible. important note plausibility judgments inevitably depend expert knowledge can vary substantially across scientific disciplines quality research design. observational study without randomization rich set measured confounders, hard rule latent confounders explaining 1% residual variation instrument. seems case Card example, residual geographic confounders plausibly attain strength. contexts, however, value 1% may large – instance, Mendelian randomization study main concern pleiotropy. also important emphasize sensitivity unobserved variables distinct “weak instruments” problem. latter depends sample size, whereas former . Instruments deemed “strong” conventional statistics (e.g., large F-statistics) may still fragile face unobserved variables violate IV assumptions.

what: Instrumental Variable Estimation using the Anderson-Rubin approach — iv_fit
title: Instrumental Variable Estimation using the Anderson-Rubin approach — iv_fit
text: iv_fit computes instrumental variable estimates confidence intervals using Anderson-Rubin (AR) approach (Anderson Rubin, 1949).  approach numerically identical Fieller's theorem (Fieller, 1954). See Cinelli Hazlett (2025) discussion. AR point estimate numerically identical point estimate two-stage least squares (2SLS) given ratio reduced-form first-stage regression coefficient. Confidence intervals, however, constructed differently. 2SLS equivalent using delta-method obtain variance ratio estimator, proceeding assuming ratio asymptotically normal. approximation can fail instruments "weak." Anderson-Rubin approach instead uses test inversion procedure construct confidence intervals. procedure correct coverage regardless instrument strength, (inevitable) cost eventually obtaining unbounded confidence intervals.

what: Contour plots of omitted variable bias for IV — ovb_contour_plot
title: Contour plots of omitted variable bias for IV — ovb_contour_plot
text: Contour plots omitted variable bias sensitivity analysis instrumental variable estimates. main inputs iv_fit model, covariates used benchmarking strength omitted variables. parm = "iv" (default) contour plots IV estimate shown. horizontal axis plot shows hypothetical values partial R2 latent variables instrument. vertical axis shows hypothetical values partial R2 latent variables (pot.) outcome. contour levels represent adjusted lower limit (upper limit) Anderson-Rubin confidence interval IV estimate, t-value testing specific null hypothesis.  reference points bounds partial R2 latent variables k times “strong” observed covariate used benchmarking (see arguments kz ky). dotted red line show chosen critical threshold (instance, zero): latent variables strength (stronger) sufficient invalidate research conclusions. parm = "fs" parm = "rf", contour plots first-stage reduced-form regression shown. See, e.g, ovb_contour_plot.lm. See Cinelli Hazlett (2020, 2025) details.
